title: “Pro-Life” Admin Nixes Policy Requiring Hospitals to Perform Lifesaving Abortions
article_text: Cool news out of thewomen-lovingTrump administration: Hospitals are no longer required to perform emergency abortions in order to save a pregnant person’s life. Yes, from the guy who brought us “I respect women, I love women, I cherish women” comesEh, they can die. On Tuesday, the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Servicesannouncedthat it wasrescinding2022 guidance issued by the Biden administration that directed hospitals to comply with federal law and provide emergency care for all patients, even if that emergency care meant terminating a pregnancy in a state with an abortion ban. In its statement, the agency said the guidance did not “reflect the policy of this administration.” At the same time, CMS claimed that it would continue to enforce the Emergency Medical Treatment & Labor Act, a 1986 law that requires federally funded hospitals to treat or transfer patients in need of emergency care; it snarkily added that it would “work to rectify any perceived legal confusion and instability created by the former administration’s actions.” In fact, the Biden-era guidance was extremely clear: Hospitals in all states were required to attempt to save people’s lives, even if those people were pregnant (what a concept). Probably quite purposely, the statement’s language makes it extremely unclear what a physician in a state with an abortion ban can do, and what could result in their losing their license or potentially going to prison. “We’ve already seen since the overturn ofRoethat uncertainty and confusion tends to mean physicians are unwilling to intervene, and the more unwilling physicians are to intervene, the more risk there is in pregnancy,”Mary Ziegler,a professor at the University of California-Davis,toldThe New York Times.“This is not just withdrawing what the Biden administration did. It’s creating a lot of unanswered questions about what hospitals are supposed to do going forward. So more confusion means more risk.”Lawrence O. Gostin,a Georgetown University health law expert, told theTimesthat it’s more than obvious what the new guidance is trying to do, regardless of the spin: “It basically gives a bright green light to hospitals in red states to turn away pregnant women who are in peril.” At least three women in Texasdiedbetween 2021 and 2023 after being denied abortion care. Meanwhile, a woman in Georgia who was declared brain-dead in February is beingkept on life supportbecause she was about nine weeks pregnant when she was admitted to an Atlanta hospital. title: Meghan Markle Celebrates Princess Lilibet’s Birthday With a Video of Her Birth Day
article_text: On Tuesday,Princess Lilibet of Sussexturned four, and her mother,Meghan Markle,is celebrating with a series of Instagram posts showing new views of her andPrince Harry.The first post features one photo of Meghan wearing a linen shirt and holding her daughter on a boat and one taken soon after Lili’s birth in June 2021. “Happy birthday to our beautiful girl!” the Duchess of Sussex wrote. “Four years ago today she came into our lives—and each day is brighter and better because of it. Thanks to all of those sending love and celebrating her special day!” She returned later with a post featuring one photo of Harry and Lili soon after her birth, and another that shows them walking on the beach. Later on, Meghan shared another memory from the past, a hilarious video showing her and Harry dancing in their hospital room before Lili was born. The video is set to “The Baby Momma Dance,” by Starrkeisha, a viral YouTube hit from 2013, and Meghan and Harry both show off their moves for the camera. “Four years ago today, this also happened,” the duchess said in a post that also featured a cry-laughing emoji. “Both of our children were a week past their due dates… so when spicy food, all that walking, and acupuncture didn’t work—there was only one thing left to do!” This content can also be viewed on the site itoriginatesfrom. Lili, the second child of Meghan andPrince Harry,was named in honor of her great-grandmother, Queen Elizabeth, who was called “Lilibet” by her parents and sister. The late queen did get to meet her namesake during the Platinum Jubilee weekend in 2022, but no photographer was present. When she was born, her name was announced as “Lilibet Diana Mountbatten-Windsor,” but when her grandfather,King Charles III,ascended to the throne in September 2022, she became eligible for the title of princess, andthe palace updated its official websiteto reflect the changein March 2023. Lili is two years younger than her brother,Prince Archie of Sussex,and she was born about one year after Meghan and Harry left their royal roles and moved from the UK to Southern California. Though official photographs of Archie were released soon after his birth, the public didn’t see an image of Lili until one year later, when photographerMisan Harrimanshareda portraitthat he took at her birthday party during the Jubilee weekend. Though Meghan and Harry have attempted to keep their daughter’s face out of any subsequent images, Lili has played a role onher mother’s Instagram account, reflecting the duchess’s evolving feelings about social media. She has also been a part of the press rollout for Meghan’s new lifestyle company, As Ever. When Meghan debuted the brand’s name and visual identity in February, its website featured a photo of the duchess and her daughter running together across a grassy field. This week, Meghan spoke toTina Knowles,mother and business partner toBeyoncé,for her podcastConfessions of a Female Founder,asking for tips about running a mother-and-daughter business. “I wonder if one day I’ll be in business with Lili, and we’ll be building something together,” the duchess said. title: Inside 'Squid Game' Season 2’s Killer Merry-Go-Round Competition
article_text: Squid GamecreatorHwang Dong-hyukcan still remember playing Mingle, a schoolyard game in which contestants must form groups based on numbers that are called out. If you’re left without a group, you’re out. In Hwang’s memory, one game came down to him, his best friend, and one other boy. The number “two” was called out. “If we two just hugged each other, then we would be done,” he says. “But somehow we were fighting for the little guy, and we were kind of holding onto his arm trying to form a team of two.” Hwang knew early on that he would include Mingle in thesecond season of his hit seriesSquid Game.The game has a lot of built-in tension—which ramps up significantly if the repercussion of losing is death. “Mingle is a game that sometimes makes you team up, which connotates solidarity, but also sometimes you have to abandon people,” he tellsVanity Fairthrough a translator. “So it has both sides. It’s about unity, but also about dividing between people.” In the season’s sixth episode, the surviving players enter a room to find a carnival-like setting arranged around a giant rotating disk. When the music stops playing, a number is revealed. They have to scramble to form groups of that number, run into one of the smaller rooms surrounding the merry-go-round, and shut the door. If a player is left without a group, they’re killed. (Watch the clip below.) It’s a dramatic game made all the more intense by the interpersonal conflict brewing between the characters—particularly Geum-ja (Kang Ae-shim) and Yong-sik (Yang Dong-geun), a mother and son who are separated in one of the most heart-wrenching scenes of the season. Hwang and his team—which included production designerChae Kyoung-sunand cinematographerKim Ji-yong—created Mingle without the use of CG so that its emotional moments could feel as realistic as possible. “This one was especially challenging because there were so many people involved,” says Hwang. “There was so much intense action going on, and then we also had the emotional trauma.” The Mingle scene was filmed at Korea’s largest soundstage, the Daejeon Studio Cube. Hwang wanted the set to feel welcoming and bright; Chae took inspiration from the design of family-friendly carnivals, especially the merry-go-rounds. “It’s a very fantasy-like carnival, but there’s a massacre going on,” says Chae. She used horse imagery throughout the design while incorporating the show’s signature square, circle, and triangle symbols. The plate really did spin, and could hold hundreds of actors—until it eventually broke down, and wouldn’t start spinning if anyone was standing on it. The team got around the issue by starting the plate while it was empty, then tasking the actors to jump on as the scene began. Sometimes, that meant getting hundreds of people to board at the same time. “So this scene was quite difficult to shoot even before calling out action, and after calling out action,” says Hwang. When Mingle is played on a playground, the participants simply hug each other to show which group they’re in. But Hwang and Chae thought forcing the characters to shut themselves into designated rooms would heighten the tension even further. “Because there’s distance between the merry-go-round and the rooms, there could be more drama,” says Hwang. “And when they do lock themselves up behind the colorful doors, there could be their own stories happening in all of those rooms.” They added a slit in each door so the players inside would see those left behind being killed. Chae adds that lighting was key to the main room’s design. She illuminated the space with 3,000 separate bulbs. “When people set their foot on the set, they were like, ‘Oh, this is really pretty.’ I think that is partially thanks to the shiny and sparkly light bulbs that were hanging there,” says Chae. Kim employed strobe lighting once the game began to add to the feeling of chaos in the room. “We have 200 or more people in the background, and not all of them are professional actors, so we were able to hide a bit with it,” says Kim. “But even for actors in the foreground, it enhanced this chaotic moment.” Kim almost felt like a player himself, running with the actors to get the most intimate shots he could of their panicked faces. His work stands out in the pivotal moment when Geum-ja and Yong-sik are separated. For Hwang, that scene was all about capturing the conflicting emotions both characters are feeling in that moment. “Geum-ja is a very Korean mother who only knows of her son—her son is everything to her,” says Hwang. “So when Yong-sik is being dragged by the two men, she feels relieved that he’ll live. But at the same time, she’s feeling, ‘Oh, is he abandoning me?’ I wanted to really show that inner conflict that she’s having at the moment.” At first, Kang Ae-shim says there was a line in the scene where her character tells her son to go. But eventually, they nixed it, believing it didn’t accurately reflect Geum-ja’s mixed feelings. “I think my character would have a very hard time wrapping our head around what’s happening at the moment.” she says. “She feels relieved that her son might live, but she’s also very, very fearful because she might die herself.” For a moment, it seems Geum-ja might die because she can’t find a new group of three. Then Gi-hun (Lee Jung-jae) and Hwang In-ho (Lee Byung-hun) grab her up to join their team. Safely locked in their room, Geum-ja vehemently defends her son’s actions, claiming he didn’t leave her behind on purpose. Kang doesn’t view that moment as her character misrepresenting the truth. Instead, she is finding her own way to survive. “I don't think she was lying,” she says. “She really truly believes that her son is a good person—and she didn’t want people to talk badly about her son.” An Exclusive First Look atWicked: For Good The Dizzying Rise of MAHA WarriorCalley Means, RFK Jr.’s Right-Hand Man The UnsinkableKathy Bates From RFK Jr. to Patrick Schwarzenegger, a Brief Guide tothe Kennedy Family All theCast MembersThat Might LeaveSNLThis Fall Rick Steveson Rejecting Fascism at Home and Fears of Trump Abroad Mariska Hargitay Was “Living a Lie” for 30 Years. title: Pete Hegseth’s “Warrior” Rebranding Seems More About Rewriting American History
article_text: Pete Hegsethisn’t stopping with Harvey Milk. The defense secretary, it seems, is poised to strip other civil rights icons’ names from naval ships as part of his effort to “reestablish” a so-called “warrior culture” in the military. According to CBS News, the Navy isconsideringrenaming vessels honoring trailblazing Supreme Court justices Thurgood Marshall and Ruth Bader Ginsburg; the civil rights activist Medgar Evers; labor rights leaders Cesar Chavez andDolores Huerta; the abolitionist and suffragist Lucy Stone and Harriet Tubman, who freed dozens from slavery as a conductor of the Underground Railroad. The considered renamings come after Hegseth ordered the name of gay rights activist Harvey Milk—a former Navy lieutenant who was assassinated in 1978 while serving on the San Francisco Board of Supervisors—removed from an oiler. No new name has been announced for the USNSHarvey Milkor others in the class of oilers named for John Lewis, the late Congressman and civil rights icon. But a Defense Department officialtoldMilitary.com that the order to remove Milk’s name from the ship was intended to coincide with Pride Month. It’s an odious move—an act of petty, culture-war trolling masquerading as toughness and common sense. “This spiteful move does not strengthen our national security or the ‘warrior’ ethos,” former House SpeakerNancy Pelositold CBS News. “Instead, is a surrender of a fundamental American value: to honor the legacy of those who worked to build a better country.” But Hegseth seems to consider the vessel names displays of the“wokeness and weakness”he says has pervaded the United States military: The Defense secretary is “committed to ensuring that the names attached to all DOD installations and assets are reflective of the Commander-in-Chief’s priorities, our nation’s history, and the warrior ethos,” Pentagon spokesmanSean Parnellsaid in a statement Tuesday. Of course, names themselves appear to be a priority forDonald Trump—and they tap into a vision of American history filtered through the president’s narrow, warped lens. Upon returning to power in January, Trumporderedthe “restoring” of “names that honor American greatness,” which included changing Denali back to Mount McKinley, in honor of the president who never set foot in Alaska, but who—in his telling—“made our country very rich through tariffs and through talent.” The directive wasn’t just about restoring the past; it was also one of the most cartoonish exercises in pseudo-patriotic rebranding since “freedom fries.” Gulf of Mexico? Not on Trump’s watch. He denominated it the “Gulf of America”: “We do most of the work there,”he reasoned, “and it’s ours.” If his designations reflect a rather imperial conception of “American greatness,” they also speak to the particular perspective he and his allies have on US history—one where it is apparently “woke” to honor those who fought for equality, but just to honor Confederates who warred against America. “That’s right: [Fort] Bragg is back,” Hegsethsaidin March after reverting Fort Liberty back to its former name, which honored the Confederate General Braxton Bragg. Though Hegseth has framed such moves as correctives to performances of wokeness in the military, therealperformance is in his constant talk of “warrior ethos” and “warfighters,” which are as over-the-top in his effort to project strength as his flag socks and flag pocket square are in his effort to demonstrate patriotism. Speaking of flags: Trump—who has alsofloatedrechristening Veterans Day as “Victory Day”—is set to host a military parade on Flag Day to celebrate the Army’s 250th anniversary…and also, perhaps, his birthday, which also falls on June 14. He has downplayed it as a coincidence: “It’s a very important day,” TrumptoldNBC News’Kristen Welkerlast month. “It’s Flag Day.” ButMonica Crowley, the former Fox News pundit planning the expensive spectacle, regards the overlap as “providential,” and has made clear the parade will honor Trump as well as the military: “I’m sure the crowd will break out into a ‘Happy Birthday,’” shesaidonSteve Bannon’s podcast Tuesday. “We all want to make sure that we celebrate in a manner that is fitting, not just of this extraordinary president, but of our extraordinary country.” An Exclusive First Look atWicked: For Good The Dizzying Rise of MAHA WarriorCalley Means, RFK Jr.’s Right-Hand Man The UnsinkableKathy Bates From RFK Jr. to Patrick Schwarzenegger, a Brief Guide tothe Kennedy Family All theCast MembersThat Might LeaveSNLThis Fall Rick Steveson Rejecting Fascism at Home and Fears of Trump Abroad Mariska Hargitay Was “Living a Lie” for 30 Years. title: Michelle Obama Gets Why Daughter Malia Dropped Her Last Name as a New Filmmaker
article_text: Hollywood is getting to know the talents of anup-and-coming filmmakernamed Malia Ann. She’s better known asMalia Obama,the 26-year-old daughter of former presidentBarack Obamaand first ladyMichelle Obama. Last year, Malia submittedThe Heart—an 18-minute short film she wrote and directed starringTunde AdebimpeandLaTonya Borsay—to the2024 Sundance Film Festival, under only her first and middle names. Her mother understands that Malia wants to strike out on her own, but recognizes that the title of former first daughter is a tough one to shed. “Malia, who started in film, I mean, her first project, she took off her last name,” Michelle said toKate HudsonandOliver Hudsonon theirSibling Revelrypodcast June 2. “And we’re like, ‘They’re still going to know it’s you, Malia.’ But we respect that she’s trying to make her way.” Michelle and Barack, who also share 23-year-old daughterSasha Obama,understand that their kids want to veer away from any “nepo baby” labels. “They are young adult women, but they definitely went through a period in their teens years where it was the push away,” Michelle said. “They’re still doing that…. You’re trying to distinguish yourself. It’s important for my kids to feel like they’ve earned what they are getting in the world. And they don’t want people to assume they don’t work hard, that they’re just naturally handed things. They’re very sensitive to that. They want to be their own people.” “Her first film went to Sundance and all these fancy film festivals, and she didn’t useObamaas a director on the credits,” Barack Obama said on thePivot Podcastlast fall. “I was all like, ‘You do know they’ll know who you are,’” he recalled telling her. “And she was like, ‘You know what? I want them to watch it that first time and not in any way have that association.’” According to the Sundancewebsite,Malia’s debut shortThe Heartis about a lonely man grieving the death of his mother after she leaves him an unusual request in her will. In a “Meet the Artist”videoreleased ahead of the fest, she called it “an odd little story” that she hoped would make viewers “feel a bit less lonely” or remind them “not to forget about the people who are.” Malia recently directeda Nike commercialstarring WNBA starA’ja Wilson.She got her big Hollywood break interning for The Weinstein Company and on the set ofGirls.Later, she was hired aspart of the writers roomonDonald Glover’s Emmy-nominated Prime Video seriesSwarm.Malia even earned a writing credit on the show’s fifth episode, “Girl, Bye,” alongside series cocreatorJanine Nabers.“She’s just like, an amazingly talented person,” Glover toldVanity Fairin 2022. “She’s really focused, and she’s working really hard…. I feel like she’s just somebody who’s gonna have really good things coming soon. Her writing style is great.” An Exclusive First Look atWicked: For Good The Dizzying Rise of MAHA WarriorCalley Means, RFK Jr.’s Right-Hand Man The UnsinkableKathy Bates From RFK Jr. to Patrick Schwarzenegger, a Brief Guide tothe Kennedy Family All theCast MembersThat Might LeaveSNLThis Fall Rick Steveson Rejecting Fascism at Home and Fears of Trump Abroad Mariska Hargitay Was “Living a Lie” for 30 Years. title: Welcome to Praxis: The High-Tech, High-Testosterone Eden That Will Save the World
article_text: Dryden Brownis a slight man of 29, with a scruffy, reddish beard and a wry, serious demeanor. On the April afternoon we met at the Beverly Hills Hotel, his dark suit seemed out of place in the sunlit ease of the Polo Lounge patio. But perhaps the suit bolsters Brown’s title: CEO and cofounder of a “network state” called Praxis, which is not so much a business as it is an ongoing campaign for a city that has yet to exist. Over the years, this campaign has largely consisted of throwing lavish parties at insular Manhattan clubs, creating company swag in the form of steel Praxis “visas,” and, every couple years, suggesting that Praxis may have found itsnew home. Here is what we know about the city so far: It will be beautiful. Also, it will restore Western civilization, through something called an “acceleration zone,” described onthe Praxis websiteas a special economic zone that will “accelerate technological progress” in areas like AI, biotech, and energy. To do so, Praxishasraisedabout a half billion dollars from the likes ofSam Altman’s Apollo Projects,Shervin Pishevar, CameronandTyler Winklevossthrough Winklevoss Capitol, and built an online community of nearly 89,000 prospective citizens. These citizens are representative of the new right-leaning tech aristocracy: people working for defense tech companies like Anduril and Palantir, three DOGE employees, and members of the influential venture fund Andreessen Horowitz. Brown has no shortage of ideas about how Praxis will save Western civilization, a problem he first became fascinated with while interning atBill Ackman’s hedge fund, Pershing Square, which recentlybackedHoward Hughes Holdings, a company developing master-planned communities like Summerlin, Nevada, and the Woodlands, Texas. But it wasn’t until the election ofJoe Bidenin 2020 that Brown realized that America was, as he puts it, becoming “a wasteland,” helmed by a “king in a coma.” To rescue it, Brown decided to build a city founded on Western values, replete with Gothic architecture and filled with a citizenry that upholds classical values and enjoys reading books likeThe Odyssey. But Brown has long grappled with the project’s most fundamental question: where, exactly, to put it. Nearly six years ago, Brown began scouting the globe for his city’s home. On a dozen adventures, he surveyed countries in the Mediterranean like Italy, Greece, and Montenegro. More recently, he floated Greenland. The Polo Lounge, a favorite meeting spot of Brown’s, seems exactly the kind of place he aspires to replicate in Praxis. After all, this is a man who is keenly sensitive to both architecture and ambiance, a man who hasspoken abouthis aspirations to build a city that has a “neo–Gilded Age” aesthetic. Amid the pink bougainvillea and April sunshine, the solicitous white-suited waiters standing at the ready in terra-cotta archways, Brown announces that he has reached a decision. As it turns out, after all these long years of scouring the earth, Praxis will build right here, in America, about a three-hour drive from the sun-dappled patio where we are currently sitting, and one hour north of Santa Barbara, the old-money coastal town where Brown grew up. The new city will be called Atlas. “The opportunity,” he told me, “is to build on Vandenberg.” Vandenberg is a 100,000-acre US Space Force base in Santa Barbara County that is home tonearly 3,000 military personneland their families. These are people who, according to Brown, are “super mission driven” and “technologically competent.” Brown believes these people need something, and what they need is mission expansion. “This is a story about California,” Brown says, his brow furrowed. “It’s also a story about America. At the highest level, it’s about building the arsenal of democracy so that if we get into a conflict with a geopolitical rival like China, we can actually compete at parity.” The idea goes like this: Let the so-called Praxians build a city on federal land in Vandenberg. They will erect facilities, housing, and offices. They will attract tech talent from nearby Los Angeles and San Francisco. With their newfound city, they will help revitalize American manufacturing. They will build drones and ships and space infrastructure. In doing so, Vandenberg will become the new American industrial base and a proud emblem of Western prowess. In Vandenberg, one gets the sense that Brown is only just getting started. “When I think about Vandenberg…like,What is Vandenberg?” Here, he seemed to ponder the possibilities. “Vandenberg is a spaceport. It’s a portal to the stars. What are the stars? What is out there? It’s a great theater for heroism, for heroic exploration. It’s, like,space…space is not about mining rocks. It’s not about getting some metal off some rocks—that is gonna be handled by AI and robots. What it’s about is building new cultures and new worlds. That’s what it’s about. It’s about expanding human civilization to new places and giving it new forms.” Space exploration is one of the subjects on which Brown has a tendency to monologue. Others, as the name of the new city suggests includeAyn Rand’sAtlas Shrugged,as well as the ideological foundation of America, and Western aesthetics. Like other libertarians, Brown has long been inspired by Rand’s capitalist utopia, Galt’s Gulch. He speaks fondly of the Founding Fathers, framing his own mission in the mythic terms of a knight’s search for the Holy Grail. During the course of our 90-minute conversation, he mentioned the word “hero” five times. Cities backed by technologists are not exactly a new idea. In recent years, tech billionaires have rolled out one sweeping blueprint after another—envisioning utopian hubs of innovation marked by walkable cities, clean energy, smart infrastructure, and gleaming high-rises. One such project isCalifornia Forever, which is backed by a string of blue-chip Silicon Valley investors likeMarc Andreessen, Michael Moritz,andReid Hoffman.One comparative advantage to Praxis’s designs on Vandenberg is that California Forever has alreadysecuredmore than 50,000 acres of land northeast of San Francisco, largely zoned for agricultural use only. But, according to Brown, there is one big problem with California Forever: “Candidly, California Forever is a really boring center-left project,” he says, that is “pandering to the local communities and the farmers or something…. These are boomer, lower-middle-class farmers who hear about Marc Andreessen and are like, ‘This guy seems weird,’” said Brown. “It is low testosterone.” What Brown is building is “more like the Gundo”—thehard-tech hub of El Segundojust south of Los Angeles that has lately become a breeding ground for companies working in defense tech and manufacturing. “This is aJetsons/pioneer/1950s/space-futurism insane city on federal land. It is a revival of the aesthetic, classical ideas in America. It is a high-testosterone futuristic vision versus the chill, community-oriented one.” It is this vision, Brown argues, that is more culturally aligned with America’s future. There is a bifurcation in American culture that Brown likens to the 2010-era competition between Lyft and Uber. Lyft were the good guys; they put pink mustaches on their cars. Uber, meanwhile, was hardcore. “Under Biden, you’d call a Lyft,” he says. “Under Trump, you call an Uber. We’re in Uber world now.” What Uber world consists of are people like Brown who helped pioneer many of the staples of our current masculine era: “We were thinking about the Roman Empire, we had the knight’s armor in our loft, we were drinking, like, raw milk and raw eggs,” says Brown. “We were going to the gym a lot.Sol Brahand the esoteric bodybuilder people…it was a whole thing. It was a countercultural movement, and now itisthe culture. We won.” So, what is actually being done—aside from conversing with a journalist on the subject—to build a new city on Vandenberg? Key to Brown’s decision to build Atlas on American soil is the election ofDonald Trump,whose mission to make America great again vibes with Brown’s own plans to revitalize Western culture. On the campaign trail,Trump promisedto build 10 new cities on federal land that would inspire innovation and manufacturing. These plans, unfortunately for Brown, have seemingly fallen by the wayside during the president’s dizzying first few months in office. Still, it is easy to see how someone with a vibrant proposal for a new American industrial base—for instance, Brown himself—might gently remind the president of hisearlier intentionto build cities that would “reopen the American frontier” and “reignite the American imagination.” But so far, Praxis has yet to secure an Enhanced Use Lease, the permission typically needed to build on the base. When I asked Brown if he was speaking to anyone in the Trump administration about building Atlas on Vandenberg, he grew evasive. “We’ve had a bunch of conversations with a bunch of different people,” he said. “We are private people. We’re a start-up. We’ve been greatly inspired by what they’ve done, by the agenda, and by the conviction around the tariffs and so on.” Then he began speaking abstractly about the process of building a city on federal land, which, to be fair, sounds like a lot of paperwork. For now, there is much that stands in the way of all this testosterone, ample though it may be. Chief among Brown’s concerns: a small, “stupid” bird called the snowy plover that is, as Brown puts it, always “pooping on everything.”Protected under the Endangered Species Act, the bird nests along the Pacific coast, and Vandenberg enforcesannual beach restrictionsduring its nesting season. Last summer, one of Vandenberg’s beaches was forced tocloseentirelyfor nearly three monthsdue to violations. The snowy plover has becomesomething of a mascotfor the California Coastal Commission, the restrictive environmental agencyattackedby Republicans and Democrats alike for limiting construction along the coast. In addition to the little bird, Brown is up against the chokehold of Californian bureaucracy that has long foiled construction projectsas minor as public toilets. Wouldn’t it be easier, I suggested to Brown, to build in a place that was slightly more friendly to his techno-masculine vision of the future? Take Texas, for instance, which has recently become the site ofElon Musk’s company town, Starbase. Here, Brown curtly shook his head as though I had said something stupid. “I’m from California,” he said. “I want to build in California.” It was as simple as that. Besides, who wouldn’t want to build in coastal California? It’s got moderate temperatures, flowering jacarandas, and rocky coastline. The sun was beginning to set and it was time for me to go. Brown had plans with someone else, a fellow Praxian who was meeting him at the Polo Lounge for dinner. (Another primary function of leading a network state, it seems, is networking.) As I stood to leave, I noticed a young man stepping out onto the patio. Even before he introduced himself, I knew he was the Praxian. He looked exactly like the Western aesthetic ideal of a man, which is to say that he looked like a Ralph Lauren model, circa 1980: tall, pale, broad-shouldered, and dressed in a preppy white knit sweater. His name was Samuel. “You must be so excited,” I told Samuel as I put on my jacket. “For your city by the sea.” But Samuel did not know what I was talking about; Brown had not yet informed him of the whereabouts of his future home. Still, it was not the location that mattered so much to him. “I’m flexible,” Samuel said. “I’m ready.” And why wouldn’t he be? His eyes were shining with possibilities for the future. He knew, after all, that it belonged to him. title: House Republicans Shocked to Learn Bill They Didn’t Read Has Stuff in It They Don’t Like
article_text: Like small children suddenly learning their actions have consequences—or cynical grown-ups scrambling to cover their asses—a number of House Republicans are now claiming they did not realize what was in theGOP spending billthey voted for last month, and had someone told them, they would not have voted “yes.” One day afterElon MuskdubbedDonald Trump’s “big, beautiful bill” a “disgusting abomination,” RepresentativeMarjorie Taylor Greenetook to X to tell her followers that there is no way she would have voted in favor of the legislation had she known it contained a measure she doesn’t like. “Full transparency, I did not know about this section on pages 278-279 of the OBBB that strips states of the right to make laws or regulate AI for 10 years,” the Georgia congressperson wrote. “I am adamantly OPPOSED to this and it is a violation of state rights and I would have voted NO if I had known this was in there.” This content can also be viewed on the site itoriginatesfrom. Several hours later, RepresentativeScott Perrytook to X to declare Musk was “right to call out House Leadership” for voting for the bill,saying“I wish I had a nickel for every time the @freedomcaucus sounded the alarm and nobody listened, only to find out the hard way we were right all along.” What Perry didn’t note is that all but one member of the House Freedom Caucus voted yes for the bill, including Perry.* Surely an honest oversight! This content can also be viewed on the site itoriginatesfrom. Greene and Perry’s mea culpas follow that of RepresentativeMike Flood,whosaidin a town hall last week that he he was unaware the bill would limit judges’ abilities to hold people in contempt, and that he would not have voted for it if he was aware of the measure. It’s not clear if these lawmakers actually didn’t read the bill they voted for—which would be pretty bad given that’s their, y’know,job—or if they knew all along and are suddenly now pleading ignorance because they realize how deeply unpopular the legislation may turn out to be. On Tuesday, SenatorRand Paulwarned: “Once this bill votes, and this debt ceiling goes through, the debt is owned by the GOP, and there is no more campaigning and saying ‘this is the Democrats.’ It will be owned by the Republicans, and I think that’s a huge mistake.” Shortly after his “disgusting abomination” post, Muskwrote: “In November next year, we fire all politicians who betrayed the American people.” He left out the part about how he spent hundreds of millions of dollars to elect Trump, a.k.a., the guy who wants this bill passed more than anyone. Probably another mere oversight! Speaking of Musk, while he has been slamming the bill over the trillions it is expected to add to the national debt, there may be another reason he’s come out so vociferously against it: the billions of dollars Tesla isexpectedto lose as a result of the legislation scrapping tax credits for electric vehicles. *RepresentativeAndy Harrisvoted “present.” An Exclusive First Look atWicked: For Good The Dizzying Rise of MAHA WarriorCalley Means, RFK Jr.’s Right-Hand Man The UnsinkableKathy Bates From RFK Jr. to Patrick Schwarzenegger, a Brief Guide tothe Kennedy Family All theCast MembersThat Might LeaveSNLThis Fall Rick Steveson Rejecting Fascism at Home and Fears of Trump Abroad Mariska Hargitay Was “Living a Lie” for 30 Years. title: Taylor Swift Celebrated Buying Back Her Masters With “Tears of Joy,” While Travis Kelce’s Approach Involves Much More Shimmying
article_text: When she announced last Friday that she had finally purchased back the master recordings and all associated material for her first six albums,Taylor Swiftwrotein an emotional letter posted to her website that she had “been bursting into tears of joy at random intervals ever since I found out that this was really happening.” Her boyfriendTravis Kelce, however, celebrated the news in his own way: Evidently, it makes him feel like dancing—and recruiting two fellow sports legends to do so. On thelatest episode ofNew Heights, the podcast Travis co-hosts with brotherJason Kelce, published Wednesday, the siblings hosted basketball hall of famerShaquille O’Nealfor a lengthy interview. There was a lot of baller talk, sure, but the most baller discussion came in the final seconds of the interview, when Shaq pulled out his phone during the outro and mumbled, “I gotta show you guys something. Two seconds." “Take your time,” Jason told him. Time well spent: Shaq tapped the phone's screen and Swift’s “I Knew You Were Trouble,” from her albumRed, blasted out of its speaker. Immediately, all three men started shimmying and lip-syncing to the track. This content can also be viewed on the site itoriginatesfrom. “My favorite song in the world, brother!” Shaq declared. Travis, never one to pass up a chance to show off his status as Swift’s No. 1 fan, proudly shot back, “Just got that song back, too, just bought all that music back too, so it’s finally hers.” While it’s not immediately clear from the snippet whether the song inspiring the dance extravaganza is from the originalRedorRed (Taylor’s Version), it doesn’t really matter: She owns them both now. Shaq has long been a confirmed Swiftie, and even told Page Six ahead of the 2024 Super Bowl, in which Travis’ Kansas City Chiefsbested the San Francisco 49ers, that just meeting the singer would make the whole game experience a touchdown, no matter the outcome: “If I see Taylor Swift and get to shake her hand, take a picture, I’ll be good,” he said. Mission accomplished:Shaq not only met Swift, but gifted her a bedazzled Judith Leiber purse, shaped like a football and customized with 87, Travis’ jersey number. Swift wore it to the game to accessorize her all-black look, and the former basketball player posted photos of himself grinning alongside Swift. Jason, after the 2024 Super Bowl, recalled the atmosphere inside thesuite packed with A-Listers where he and Swift sat: “Turns out, everyone wants to meet Taylor,” he said. “Shaq came in on the frickin’ suite. I mean, dude.” “I think it was my first really understanding kind of some of the things that she has to deal with on a lot of bases because there’sso many star-studded people therethat it’s like dude, everybody wants to come see her,” Jason said. Travis added, “Taylor thrives in those situations, she’s been in 'em countless times in her life.” Of course, Shaq and the boys aren’t the only ones having dance parties. Swift has been spotted out celebrating with friends, including getting dinner at New York City’s Monkey Barwith longtime palSelena Gomezthe day after she announced the sale. Frequent collaborator and friendJack Antonoff, too,posted a video of himself and Swift(and one of her cats, Meredith, always key personnel) singing along to “Getaway Car,” a track fromReputation, which has not seen a re-release. “Rep forever guilt free listening!” he captioned the video. title: Princess Leonor Arrives in New York After Five Months at Sea
article_text: Princess Leonorhas just concluded her voyage aboard theJuan Sebastián de Elcano, a training ship used by the Spanish navy. Five months after her departure from the port of Cadiz, the heir to the throne arrived on Wednesday in New York, the ship's last stop in America, where a large group of journalists, authorities and members of the Royal Household staff were waiting for her at the Manhattan cruise terminal. Before arriving, the midshipmen paid tribute to the two mates of the Mexican training ship Cuauhtémoc, who lost their lives on May 17 when the ship collided with the Brooklyn Bridge,reports RTVE. The Royal House has confirmed that Elcano will remain docked at pier 88 of the New York port until June 10, when the companions of the Princess of Asturias are scheduled to re-embark to return to Spain. Princess Leonor of Spain arrives on board the training ship Juan Sebastian de Elcano on June 04, 2025 in New York City. Princess Leonor will return to Spain by plane, but during the next few days she will take part, together with the other midshipmen, in the activities scheduled for this stopover. According to¡Hola!this week, one of these activities will include the participation, along with other Spaniards, includingVictoria de Hohenlohe,the Duchess of Medinaceli,who has been living in New York with her husband for the past two months. Another of the activities planned is the attendance at Carnegie Hall to the showA Musical Fantasy from Spain,which will be performed on Wednesday by the Orquesta Titular del Teatro Real de Madrid. Spanish Navy training ship Juan Sebastian de Elcano arrives in Pier 88 on June 04, 2025 in New York City. On the other hand, it seems that in the end there will not be a visit to the White House like that ofMidshipmanFelipe de Borbónin Reagan's time. Back in Spain, and after a brief reunion with her family, Princess Leonor has another month of naval training on a Navy frigate ahead of her. On June 16, the expected graduation will take place at the Naval School of Marin, a ceremony presided over by King Felipe, where Leonor and her classmates will receive the title of naval ensign. The heiress will join the Air and Space Academy of San Javier (Murcia) after the summer, where she will complete the third and final year of her military training. title: Renée Zellweger Embraces a New Era of Bridget Jones—and Hollywood Itself
article_text: Renée Zellwegeris on the verge of making history. If she earns an Emmy nomination for Peacock’sBridget Jones: Mad About the Boy,she’ll also become the first actress to get Oscar and Emmy nods for the same role. And that’s not just a bit of entertainment industry trivia: The possibility is emblematic of anever-changing Hollywood landscape,the rise of streaming media and the fall of traditional theatrical rom-coms. But a now 56-year-old Zellweger seems unfazed by it all. “I don’t think about it from that perspective, necessarily,” she tellsVanity Fair. “But it’s definitely interesting to introduce the character to different audiences. Yeah, it’s a new day, and it’s quite a fun pivot.” Zellweger knows a thing or two about range. After “completing”Tom CruiseinJerry Maguire,and belting from murderers’ row asChicago’sRoxie Hart, Zellweger nabbed two Oscars: a supporting actress trophy for 2003’sCold Mountainand, in 2020, followinga six-year hiatusfrom the screen, best actress for playing Judy Garland inJudy. Her re-entry into Hollywood coincided withthe streaming boom,where Zellweger led the 2019 Netflix limited seriesWhat/Ifand 2022’s NBC limited seriesThe Thing About Pam.On the day we speak, she’s fresh off shootingOnly Murders in the Buildingseason fivewith other new additions likeBeanie Feldsteinand fellow two-time Oscar winnerChristoph Waltz. “It’s ridiculous. It’s so much fun,” Zellweger says. “I’m working with some of my favorite actors and favorite people—what a way to spend the summer.” The newest entry in theBridget Jonesfranchise earned more than $100 million at the global box office and became Working Title’sbiggest post-pandemic filmto date overseas. But in the US, the film was relegated to a streaming-only release. Fighting for thefuture of movie theatersis a conversation worth having, Zellweger says. “It’s something that I talk about with my friends because we love to go and have a popcorn breakfast on a Saturday morning,” she says. “Is it more niche these days? Possibly. But I think there’s always going to be folks like me who love to go and pick a favorite seat and spend some time on a journey together with folks in our community. It’s one of those really rare moments when we can connect.” But how many entries in Zellweger’s filmography—which range from a Farrelly Brothers studio comedy to aRon Howardhistorical drama—would be impossible to make now? “Most of them,” she admits. “The majority of them, definitely.” “And that’s a shame. Because a lot of the things that I’d love to watch and revisit might not be made. There are things that I’m nostalgic for that are more difficult to find. But then again, with streaming, there’s so much [good] content if you dig around long enough.” As an example, Zellweger points to last year’sMy Old Ass,writer-directorMegan Park’scoming-of-age tale starringMaisy Stellaas a Canadian teen who meets her older self, played byAubrey Plaza,during a mushroom trip. “It was just reminiscent of a different time,” she says of the Prime Video title. “It felt like when independent films were at their zenith, and it reminded me of how much I love the immersion in those stories where you connect with these characters, and you root for them, and you feel for them, and you leave feeling just a bit different for having had the experience. Beautiful, beautiful performances, didn’t you think? Knockout.” The same could be said forMad About the Boy. In the hands of directorMichael Morrisand writersDan MazerandAbi Morgan,it’s therare fourth moviein a franchise that sticks the landing on a story that felt shakier in its last two sequels—2004’sThe Edge of Reasonand 2016’sBridget Jones’sBaby. Zellweger had total confidence in Morris’s vision for the latest entry, inspired byHelen Fielding’s2013 novel. “I loved that, when he looked at how to bring the series into the present, he talks about the importance of friendships—how they evolve over time and become vital to how we define ourselves, especially when you’re experiencing the process of bereavement,” she says. “It was important to find how she’s grown, how her values have shifted, how she carries herself differently. Where is she more measured, and what about her is undeniably familiar? He’s a deeply thoughtful director, and I felt really lucky that he was on board for this latest chapter.” Viewers are reunited with Bridget a few years after the death of her husband,Colin Firth’sMark Darcy.“He was always in my thoughts while we were making this film,” Zellweger says. “The history of that relationship is indelible—the ways in which he’s shaped Bridget’s life.” That’s also true ofHugh Grant’seternal bachelor, Daniel Cleaver,who has found friendly peace with Bridget after a few failed attempts at a romantic relationship. “Oh, it’s wonderful, and it’s such familiar territory sharing the Daniel-Bridget universe,” she says. “I love my days with Hugh.” Two new prospects enter Bridget’s life inMad About the Boy. The first isWhite LotusbreakoutLeo Woodallas Roxster McDuff, a 29-year-old park ranger who proves to be more than a May-December fling. The other is Oscar-nominated actorChiwetel Ejioforas Mr. Wallaker, a no-nonsense science teacher at Bridget’s children’s school. But unlike Bridget’s past films, dating here is secondary to her role as a mother to her elementary-aged children, Billy(Casper Knopf)and Mabel(Mila Jankovic). Knopf, who skillfully mimics Firth’s soulful, soft-spoken nature, “is just a pro already,” she says. As for Jankovic: “If you were to conjure Bridget’s child, there she is. She’s the manifestation, surely. Her energy and her joie de vivre—she’s a whirling dervish of wonderful.” Bridget has changed since the early aughts, but Zellweger’s commitment to the role has never wavered. “I just feel really lucky to have shared another round in Bridget’s world with people and this character that I love so much,” she says. “It’s such an unusual opportunity to revisit a character and discover her anew.” In the years since her husband’s sudden death, Bridget Jones has been on autopilot. Then, she’s reminded of advice from her late father, played byJim Broadbentvia flashback inMad About the Boy. “It’s not enough to survive: You have to live,” he tells her. It’s those words that rouse Bridget from her grief and renew her zest for new experiences. Zellweger knows this feeling well: She, too, made the decision to live more life when she took a self-imposed break from acting in 2010. After six years away from the spotlight, “I recognized myself again, when I had a life instead of just a profession,” she toldVanity Fairin 2020. “When I had friends who I saw on a regular basis.” I ask Zellweger if she ever seriously considered giving up acting. “That’s an interesting question that I don’t think that I’d even asked myself,” she says, considering her next words. “I mean, if that’s what needed to happen, and if that’s where the journey led, then okay. But I wasn’t really making any plans. I was just acknowledging what was necessary at the time to feel like I could grow a little bit.” Zellweger says the work “certainly” felt different after her hiatus. She can appreciate the symmetry of playing Bridget two times before the pause and twice more afterwards, but doesn’t seem especially eager to delve into how the experiences differed. Perhaps keeping some things close to the vest is another lesson learned during Zellweger’s interlude. Gaining some perspective paid off, according to Leo Woodall. He calls Zellweger “the warmest person in the world,”tellingVF:“She’s carrying this whole thing on her back, so I wanted part of my job to be serving whatever she needs.” The feeling was mutual. “Isn’t Leo wonderful?” Zellweger asks in her gentle Southern twang. “I so look forward to watching where his career leads him—such a gifted actor and a wonderful person.” Zellweger doesn’t take the responsibility of leading a set lightly. “I’ve worked with some of the most talented and highly revered filmmakers in the world. And the unconditional kindness of a lot of the number ones that I’ve had the good fortune to get to know really left an impression,” she says. “I recognize the work for what it is. It’s a blessing. You’re lucky to get to do what you love as a profession, and it’s a miracle every time a project makes its way into production. It doesn’t work without the contribution of every single person on that set. So the collaboration, it’s essential, and that’s my favorite thing about the experience of storytelling.” While on her break from acting, Zellwegerstudied screenwriting,but has no current plans to pen a Bridget adventure of her own “This [story] is very specific to Helen’s experiences. She shares her own most intimate life moments through the character of Bridget, so authorship belongs to her alone,” Zellweger says. “I feel lucky as an interpretive artist to come in and take what’s there and bring it to life.” What about another project? “Sure. Yeah, there’s some different experiences I’d like to have in the future,” she says coyly. And though there is a finality to Bridget’s journey inMad About the Boy, Zellweger hasn’t ruled out a return, either. “Everybody who’s involved feels such affection for this character and wants to protect the integrity of the experience,” she says. “That Helen might want to tell more stories through the character…I’d feel really lucky about that.” An Exclusive First Look atWicked: For Good The Dizzying Rise of MAHA WarriorCalley Means, RFK Jr.’s Right-Hand Man The UnsinkableKathy Bates From RFK Jr. to Patrick Schwarzenegger, a Brief Guide tothe Kennedy Family All theCast MembersThat Might LeaveSNLThis Fall Rick Steveson Rejecting Fascism at Home and Fears of Trump Abroad Mariska Hargitay Was “Living a Lie” for 30 Years. title: Balenciaga and Britney Spears Collaborate on a Capsule Collection
article_text: Toconclude his ten yearsat the helm of Balenciaga in style,DemnainvitedBritney Spearsto collaborate on his final ready-to-wear act for spring 2026, titled “Exactitudes.” Beneath the minimalism of the collection's name lies a dense emotional and visual charge. It captures and celebrates Balenciaga “archetypes,” the result of his questioning of the contemporary wardrobe during his time at the label founded by Cristóbal Balenciaga in 1917. "The people, silhouettes, vibes and ideas that have been fundamental to my work for this amazing house," Demna said in a press release, which accompanies a reinterpretation of the signature red bomber from his very first Balenciaga show, the famous "mask" glasses through to the exaggerated multi-layered anoraks from the winter 2018 collection. The artistic director will present his last couture show for the house in July 2025 and will be replaced byPierpaolo Piccioli. Balenciaga spring 2026 collection The capsule series between Balenciaga and Spears, an already iconic collaboration between the most divisive pop star of the 2000s and the designer who transformed the brand, takes the form of an homage but with the gritty DNA that has made the house so successful. The collection features worn T-shirts, XXL hoodies, studded caps and silk twill flags screen-printed withRankinandSteve Kleinphotographs, all with Spears's autograph in azure blue or Barbie pink. Add an assertive Y2K varnish, and the result is something that blurs the line between an artist's merchandise and museum artifact. Kitsch becomes luxury and Spears becomes muse. A synthesis that's not so much a wink as a manifesto. Fashion doesn't document pop culture, it absorbs it, transforms it, archives it and resells it. To this wardrobe is added, of course, a playlist, an accessory now as essential asthe City, the label's it-bag. Curated by Spears herself and hosted on Balenciaga's Music Hub, it blends her personal inspirations with two remixes byBFRND, the house's faithful sound composer and Demna's partner. "Britney is a pioneer, she defined pop music and inspired generations of artists, reworking her legacy is a great honor," said the musician. “Gimme More” becomes the podium soundtrack, whileOops!... I Did It Againcelebrates its 25th anniversary in an electro-funeral setting. All that's missing is confetti and a strobe light. Britney Spears' playlist for Balenciaga “I've always loved fashion and I was so honored and delighted that Balenciaga and Demna chose to collaborate with me on Demna's latest collection for the house. I hope my fans love it as much as I do! These are some of my favorite images from an extraordinary period in my career and life, and I can't wait to share them with everyone,” declared the singer. A privilege that Balenciaga has previously only granted toRuPaul,Aya Nakamuraand the metal band Rammstein. This capsule also marks a passing of the torch. After transforming the house into a black mirror of our times fusing oversized sportswear, social satire and haute couture references, Demna will head to Gucci next. title: How Rob Franklin Wrote 'Great Black Hope,' the Novel You’ll See by Every Hamptons Lounger This Summer
article_text: One ofGreat Black Hope’s earliest images of its protagonist, David Smith (called Smith), is a mug shot. Booked on a possession charge after a cocaine bump in a Hamptons night club, “he’d worn,”Rob Franklinwrites in his debut novel, one of the first releases relaunchingSummit Books, “a vintage Marni gingham shirt, loose-fit linen trousers, and a gently startled expression.” Smith is a product of two societies: a louche New York cohort of moneyed, mostly white 20-somethings with jobs like Smith’s (flunky at a DTC art world start-up) or none at all, and the more decorous world of his hometown, Atlanta, where his father dwells as a retired HBCU president. Following the death of Smith’s best friend and roommate, Elle England, the socialite daughter of a former soul star, his train starts to come off the rails. Soon after: the mug shot. With pathos, style, and a laser trained on details that straddle the devastating and the devastatingly wry (at one point, Smith awakens in a strange bed less worried about the man next to him than that he’s landed in the quagmire of Bushwick; in another, he imagines that the only lawyer he’d be able to afford without family intervention would be of the “1-800-GET-U-OFF” variety), the book follows Smith’s Sisyphean struggle with the legal system, alongside the increasingly headline-grabbing details of Elle’s death. (One plot thread finds a fictional writer from this very magazine—albeit one with an unusual fact-checking process—reporting a feature on the story.) 'Great Black Hope' by Rob Franklin Simon & Schuster There’s perhaps no one better suited to discuss the work thanMargo Jefferson,Pulitzer Prize–winning critic, investigator of the personal and political, andchronicler and problematizer of America’s Black elite. In fact, Jefferson, or at least her writing, nearly made a cameo in the novel. In the book’s middle section, Smith returns home to Atlanta, where he fends off setups with the daughters of his parents’ friends and watches his sister do battle with their grandmother over whether their family has predatory landlording to thank for its good fortune. Franklin, who populated Smith’s father’s personal library with the work of E. Franklin Frazier, Frantz Fanon, and bell hooks as a way to “have some of those icons of Black scholarship enter into the world of the novel,” nearly slipped Jefferson’s 2015 memoir,Negroland,onto the shelf, before deciding that “it almost felt like showing my handtoomuch.” “You’ve got a mystery, you’ve got a novel of manners,” Jefferson says ofGreat Black Hope, which is out next week—a comedy coupled with, rather than tragedy, “what Dorothy Parker called ‘the messes.’” ForVF,she and Franklin discuss the mess, the Marni, and more. Margo Jefferson: This book is so much about gradations, contradictions of coexisting privileges, situational switches. Rob Franklin:If we look at two characters like Smith and Elle, who are both products of the Black elite, they're still products of different kinds of the Black elite. Smith is from Atlanta, Southern Black bourgeoisie. His parents are professionals, an academic and a doctor. All of their friends are academics, doctors, lawyers, very much a background rooted in degrees. And a degree of wealth, but not extravagant wealth. Elle is the product of the Hollywood Black elite, and a coastal scene that has a lot more glamour, a lot more overt wealth. The people that she grew up with are the children of actors and athletes and rappers. As a result, it is a scene that’s less preoccupied with the grad school degree or whatever, but it’s also far more glamorous than what Smith is used to. Talk to me about Carolyn too. These two women are the epitome of beauty, glamour, and a certain kind of performative daring. Carolyn is his other closest friend, who is from a wealthy New York family. She’s half English, her family’s entrenched in the fine arts. There’s an East Coast pretension to her background. With both women, part of the appeal to him is the way that his proximity to them gives him access to certain rooms, and a passport to certain social affects, and things that he encodes that he otherwise would not have been exposed to. He’s really drawn to that. But especially with Carolyn, who is a white woman, he also resents that. There’s the assumption that wherever he and Carolyn went together, he had the same privilege that she did. And actually, that’s not true. He knows that his passport into those rooms is revocable and that there are certain expectations being made of him. When Smith is Carolyn’s plus-one to this restaurant opening, there’s a line about, basically, being wealthy and white of late had become unfashionable, at least without the veneer of multiculturalism. And so he is aware that what he adds to this scene of people from the East Coast, or from Europe, who have vacation homes in glamorous places. What he’s adding to their lives is a kind of cultural texture that makes them seem more interesting. There are second layers of tension. Every Black parent—bourgeois, whatever—tells their child, Don’t you dare get in one of these positions, like being arrested, because you can’t get away with it, and it will shame our family. He’s crossed some terrible line. He’s suddenly moved from the path of achievement, and twice as good, onto this other self-destructive path. He later muses on the kids who grew up with him in Atlanta, who were also in Jack and Jill, and went to prep school. Some stayed the course, and did the med school degree, and lived out the expectations of generations of their families, and others self-destructed under the oppressive expectations. You end the prologue with, “He’d worn in his mugshot a vintage Marni gingham shirt, loose-fit linen trousers, and a gently startled expression.” The performance is still going, there. It hadn’t even totally occurred to me that, yeah, our prologue ends with an image, ends with a mugshot. A very chic mugshot. Where he is, again, captured both in the tasteful, upwardly mobile external image that he tries to present to the world, what he was wearing to this club, summer linens and Marni. He’s a character who is not going to emotionally come undone in public. He’s very much trained in a comportment that doesn’t allow him to totally break down in public, even as he begins to realize the gravity of his situation. Smith’s father comes to help see him through the hearings. And of course, they’re the most well-dressed people in the room. I thought, this is another one of Rob’s jokes, because if anything, the bourgeois Black person is going to gussy it up. A long time ago, I said to a friend I’d grown up with in Chicago, “What are you wearing?” We were going to some event in New York. And she sighed and said, “I’m going to be overdressed as usual.” I thought, That’s us! Yes, the perpetual fear of being underdressed. The first time they went, they probably would’ve expected almost everyone was going to be in a suit. They think that’s what you do in a courthouse. You want to present a certain way. But then, in this weird way, in trying to fit in, they actually stand out and become that much more conspicuous. And that hangs over. Though it never hangs over Elle. She has her own destructive and grief-stricken moments, but that doesn’t hang over her. And maybe that’s the difference. She’s not, quote, “bourgeois.” She’s basically café society upper class. That’s such a good point and distinction of this question of presentation. When you are a product of a coastal, New Yorker, LA, Black elite, the question of dressing in a way that’s a little bit too extravagant, that is not so at the fore of the way that people from those milieu are trained in comportment. They feel able to stunt a bit more. She is less restricted by these codes of respectability. But then we also see in her death, and in the coverage of her death, how much straying from a respectable image, ultimately, will catch up with one, and how much a person can be punished in public view for doing that. The way media will borrow, will feed on a certain image history. “The Black woman was found in a sordid place, and her dress was torn off her…” And we see that, as you’ve written about, in pop-cultural history, in the way that glamorous Black women with issues with drugs, like Whitney Houston,Naomi Campbell,who are larger than life, incredibly glamorous women—there’s a resentment from the white media ecosystem that they’re so unapologetic, and they’re so over the top. In the coverage of their experiences with substance use, they, I think, are extra punished for [it]. Talk to me about Carolyn, and punishments that she risks. I didn’t want it to be so Black and white, as like, here’s a Black woman and a white woman in similar circumstances. Here’s how one is discarded, and here’s how the other is allowed infinite chances. I wanted it to be a little bit more complicated. Part of what I was interested in was both how these women are performing femininity, how Carolyn is embodying a particular brand of white femininity that allows her proximity to power, and makes her sexually desirable to powerful men. But also, how she feels really, really constrained by that endless performance, in a similar way to how Smith feels constrained by his performance of “respectable Negro.” Carolyn feels this mask that she’s been wearing, this performance, is a cage, and doesn’t know how to hack her way out of it. I was interested in how all these characters are performing identity, how they’re performing glamour. Smith says that the point of drugs is they obliterate time. His mother asks, “Why would you want to obliterate time?” And, with his mouth full—as she had taught him not to do!—he says, “Why wouldn’t you?” That, in a strange way, is a kind of privilege. That that generation of Blacks have entered, or descended into, a certain kind of, No, I don’t give a shit. “Obliterate time” is so different from Ellison’s “I am an invisible man.” We see three generations of Smith’s maternal lineage, because we see his mother, and we see his mother’s mother. And at the beginning of the Down South section, the middle section of the book, we get this rewind, this flashback to the grandmother’s life story, escaping the deep rural South and coming to the urban South. It’s a hair-raising story. That’s a kind of Black novelistic legacy that you’ve entered into, for a time. I went back and forth on if that section should be cut, where to put it. Why I wanted to preserve it is precisely because of this question of time. Giving a sense of the generational upward, uphill battle. Lifting as we climb. The grandmother, who was born on a sharecropping farm and becomes a lawyer, ascends into the middle class, or the upper middle class, then produces these children who go to Ivy League schools and become professionals. Smith’s a third-generation product of that, who has, as you said, the privilege of wanting to obliterate time. Wanting to indulge to a point that is self-destructive, as a way of shirking the very high expectations and responsibilities he knows are being thrust upon him, but in a slightly rebellious, “fuck this” way. We can see 70 years, 80 years of history over the course of this novel. And all of that uphill climbing can be obliterated in a single night. Which isalsosomething he wants to obliterate, having to fear it, having to be aware of it. He’s a character that really struggles with embodiment, presenting as himself in different rooms, and the anxious hyperattunement to his body that that creates. He’s a character that also struggles with the anxiety innate to having to figure out what it is a person is supposed to do with their life. I was interested [in the character names]. I suddenly realized,Elle, my God: she, her. She’s such a symbol. The names: David Smith, I wanted him to have this everyman name, but then to take Smith as his first name in a way that makes it tasteful, distinct, chic. With Elle England, because her mother’s this soul singer, I wanted their names to have that stagey quality. It made me think immediately of that generation of Black women performers who were taken up by English rock stars. Then I looked up Carolyn. A lot of women are named Carolyn. Its origin is “free man.” There is something that feels classic about the name Carolyn. I did want her to have a slightly old-world aspect. I was also thinking aboutCarolyn Bessette. I knew you were. That brand of elegant ’90s white femininity was definitely coming into play. Names are so tricky. But then, some of them, the name Fernanda, which is for a relatively minor character, I came across this old story, I think in theNew York Post,of this debutante namedFernanda Wanamaker Wetherill. She’s infamous. In the front half of the 20th century, she had a big debutante ball in the Hamptons. Her family rented a nearby estate for an after-party. Her friends went completely wild. They were using china for target practice. Someone was swinging from a chandelier that came detached from the ceiling and fell to the floor. It was covered in thePostand other gossip rags, as the symbol of the ultrarich, the decadence and godlessness of the ultrarich. I like when writers do those kinds of things because you can bring your own association to it, but if you don’t get it, you’re fine. [Elle and Carolyn’s] mothers have both achieved, in certain ways, more than they’ve done. What they can do, so far, is invent themselves as performers and beauties. Both of them are very much still in the process of becoming, and have mastered a level of self-invention, but haven’t figured out the ends to put that towards. Both of their mothers are originally performers. Carolyn’s mother is a ballet dancer turned child psychologist, and Elle’s mother is a soul singer. These are women who used performance to gain a foothold in the world. Their daughters learned the skill of performance, but still haven’t sorted what to do with it. One doesn’t feel the same way about [the character] O. One feels, somehow or another, that they are going to find a way. Maybe because they’re outside of the borders of the world that Smith and Carolyn and Elle know how to navigate. There’s a twinning happening between Smith and O. But O represents this more liberated path, where O is unconstrained by the fixedness of identity. Their identity is a much more slippery thing. We see through that character the immutability of being able to change one’s identity, and all the power in that. They are very exciting to Smith for that reason. He’s totally drawn to this idea that even though, of course, projections will always be placed on you, there is a way to exist without that being a constant mental strain. When I was crafting their relationship, I was thinking about many things. A book that I was thinking about a lot when I was writing this book wasWhite GirlsbyHilton Als.The duality, the idea of twinning. I was almost thinking about two different aspects of my own psyche, of a part that’s so steeped in history and in familial expectations—and then a part that represents future and possibility. This interview has been edited and condensed. title: “Butthurt” Elon Musk Has Billions of Reasons to Hate the GOP Spending Bill
article_text: Elon Muskspent much of Tuesday—and the early hours of Wednesday morning—raging againstthe “big, beautiful” spending bill thatPresident Donald Trumpis trying to push through the Republican-led Senate. “This immense level of overspending will drive America into debt slavery!” Muskwroteon X at 2:14 am Eastern, doing little to dispel rumors that he isfrequently hopped up on drugs. He called the bill a “disgusting abomination” and promised to “fire all politicians who betrayed the American people” who voted for it. Musk says he hates the bill because it is expected to drive up the deficitby nearly $4 trillion. But, as White House sources have been quick to tell reporters over the last 24 hours, there are other reasons why the billionaire Tesla CEO is lashing out. As one sourceput it simply to Axios, “Elon was butthurt.” Among other things (like, oh,healthcare coverage and food stamps) the GOP bill would scrap electric vehicle tax credits that Tesla has benefited from.According to Politico, the EV maker stands to lose billions of dollars from tax credits that would expire this year under the current version of the bill. “When businessmen criticize legislation, journalists don’t take them at their word, they look at how the legislation would impact their business interests,” a Republican source told Politico. “They should be doing that in this case.” Axios’s sources, meanwhile, said Musk may also be feeling the sting from President Trump’s decision to withdraw the nomination of Musk palJared Isaacmanas NASA Administrator. According toThe New York Times, thepresident informedMusk of the decision on Friday, the same day as Musk’s big Oval Office sendoff. Musk’s allies reportedly tried to change the President’s mind, to no avail. Trump pulled the nomination after whathe saidwas a “thorough review of prior associations,” a likely nod to Isaacman’s past donations to Democrats. “I'm pretty sure Elon thought the NASA situation was a last insult," one White House official told Axios. Musk’s outbursts have apparentlymade Trump “furious,”according to Fox & Friends hostBrian Kilmeade, though the president has yet to say anything about it publicly. The White House referredVanity Fairto press secretaryKaroline Leavitt’s briefing Tuesday,during which she saidthe president is “sticking to” his plan for the bill. “The president already knows where Elon Musk stood on this bill,” Leavitt said. “It doesn’t change the president’s opinion.” Trump has said he wants the bill on his desk by July 4th, but it faces an uphill battle in the narrowly divided Senate, where Kentucky senatorRand Paulhas saidhe is “just not open to supporting” such a huge debt ceiling increase.Trump lashed outat Paul in a Truth Social post, writing, “He loves voting ‘NO’ on everything, he thinks it’s good politics, but it’s not.” Missouri senatorJosh Hawley, meanwhile, haspushed backagainst proposed Medicaid cuts in the bill, writing in aNew York Timesop-ed just last month that cutting off poor people’s health insurance would be “both morally wrong and politically suicidal.” But he seemed to be softening his stance earlier this week after meeting with Trump. “Just had a great talk with President Trump about the Big, Beautiful Bill. He said again, NO MEDICAID BENEFIT CUTS,”he wrote on X. Hawley, of course, is being careful with his language. The billwouldimpose new work requirements on Medicaid recipients thatexperts say would have the effect of cutting millionsof people off from insurance. Now, GOP senators find themselves having to pick sides in a no-win tug of war. On one side, is Musk, the party’s biggest donor, who has vowed to use his vast wealth to oust lawmakers from office if they vote for this bill. On the other is Trump, the party’s supreme leader and a president who has proven himself more than willing toexact vengeanceon his political rivals. In the middle? Oh, just the rest of us. title: Mike Tindall Dreams of a Rugby Super Bowl
article_text: Even after hanging up his boots, ex-rugby playerMike Tindallhas never really left the field. At 46, the former England center — world champion in 2003 and now a well-known figure in the Royal Family — is back in the spotlight with a project as ambitious as it is unexpected: the creation of R360, a brand-new international rugby league modeled on the Grand Prix. The aim? To attract the world's best players, without cutting them off from their international commitments. R360 promises to respect international windows, leaving players available to represent their countries. According to theBBC, the competition would be played mainly in the summer, from April to June and August to September, and while it would not conflict with the men's Six Nations Tournament, it would overlap with both the Southern Hemisphere Rugby Championship and the women's Six Nations Tournament. The tournament would take place in the world's largest cities: London, Paris, Los Angeles, Tokyo, Buenos Aires and Cape Town have been mentioned as potential host cities. For Tindall, this league is the answer to a crisis in rugby's appeal, particularly among the younger generation and the general public. The stated aim: to finally give rugby its equivalent of the Super Bowl, with a world league that would be the “pinnacle of rugby.” The tournament is due to be launched next year and is committed to “unleashing the potential of women's rugby,” headlined by American superstarIlona Maher. For the moment, few details have filtered out about funding or "institutional backing" for the project, although owners of teams in other sports, including the NFL andFormula 1, appear to be interested. But Tindall seems determined to shake things up and give rugby a stage worthy of its prestige, by redrawing its contours.
